We often receive questions about slow or faulty transactions. Find the answers to the most frequently asked questions below and find out directly what you can do.

Blockchair only provides blockchain search and analytics services, so there is nothing we can do to help you with your payments.

Blockchain explorer,
analytics and web services
homepage.subtitle: Explore data stored on 17 blockchains
homepage.about_title:
We develop products
that make blockchain data
accessible to individuals,
development teams, and research organizations
homepage.about_subtitle:
Blockchair is the first blockchain explorer which incorporates a multitude of different blockchains into one search engine.

Now, we are striving to make blockchain data understandable and accessible for a wide and varied audience, interested in both blockchain and crypto, while maintaining and securing the privacy of our users as a paramount when developing products.

privacy.title: Privacy is our paramount
privacy.subtitle:
Blockchair is the most private
blockchain search engine
privacy.text:
Unlike most blockchain explorers and cryptocurrency companies, we do not collect personal data, nor do we share it with third-party analytics companies and ad networks.

When using our services you do not risk any personal identifiable information becoming public or your cryptocurrency balances being leaked

search.no_results_for_:
Oops! We couldn`t find “{query}” among the information stored on blockchains.
Recheck the phrase and try again.
search.empty_query:
Oops! You haven`t entered anything into the search field.
Please enter a transaction or address hash, a block number or a text data stored on blockchains.

faq.q: Why does it take so long before my transaction is processed?
a: If you have been waiting for a long period for your transaction to be processed, the most likely reason is a low transaction fee.

Miners process transactions based on the transaction fee attached to a transaction. It can take quite some time before your transaction is processed: several minutes, hours, sometimes several days, and in some cases, it seems your transaction will never be processed!

If your transaction fee is low, it might take some time before the transaction is included in a block. To have your transaction prioritized by miners over other transactions, you can attach a higher transaction fee to your transaction, incentivizing miners to include your transaction in a block quicker.

Some wallets support functionality to increase the transaction fee.
Please reach out to your wallet or exchange to find out what you can do to have your transaction processed faster.
<cite>Blockchair does not process transactions, so we are unable to prioritize processing your transaction over other transactions.</cite>

faq.q: What can I do to speed up my transaction?
a: For Bitcoin transactions:
If your transaction has replace-by-fee (RBF) enabled, then you technically have the ability to resend the transaction with a higher transaction fee. You should resend it using your wallet.
If RBF is not enabled, then you should wait until your transaction is processed or dropped from the mempool.
For Ethereum transactions:
You should increase the transaction fee (gas price). The new parameters should be set in your wallet or by your exchange.

Not every wallet or exchange supports the function to increase the transaction fee. To check whether your wallet or exchange supports increasing the transaction fee or not, you should contact your wallet or exchange. There is nothing Blockchair can do to increase your transaction fee and have your transaction processed faster, unfortunately.

Warning!

Beware of scammers! No one can reverse your transaction and only YOU have the power to speed up your transaction. Don’t fall for scammers impersonating members of Blockchair! We will never ask for your private keys, seed phrase or mnemonic phrase.

We will not write to you first, be that in a private message on Telegram or other social media, and we do not provide support for individual requests which are unrelated to Blockchair’s products and services.

faq.q: I see that my Bitcoins are marked ‘unspent’. What does it mean?
a: In Bitcoin and Bitcoin-like networks (such as BCH, BSV, LTC and others), an ‘unspent’ status of coins means that these coins were received by an address and have not left that address yet. These coins can still be sent to someone else. You are able to transfer these coins if you own the private key related to the address on which the coins are registered. Once sent to someone else, the coins are marked as ‘spent’.

Please note that in Bitcoin and Bitcoin-like networks, a transaction usually has multiple receivers. You are only able to spend the coins that are registered to the address of which you own the related private key.

faq.q: Can I reverse a cryptocurrency transaction which was sent incorrectly?
a: Irreversibility is one of the fundamental properties of blockchain technology. Once a transaction is included in a block, it is not possible to reverse the transaction.

If you want to know whether there is still a chance to get your funds back, please contact your wallet or exchange. Blockchair does not process transactions, nor do we provide wallet services. We can not reverse transactions in public blockchains. No one can.

faq.q: Why do I see my money on Blockchair and how come Blockchair has my money?
a: Blockchain is a public distributed database of which anyone can make a copy. Your cryptocurrency transactions and address balance are also stored in such a database. However, your money and assets are not stored on Blockchair.

At Blockchair we provide insight into data that is stored in blockchains. We offer ways to find, sort, and filter blockchain data, so you can easily check your address balance and transaction history. We do not provide wallet services and do not process transactions.

faq.q: I sent Bitcoin to a Bitcoin Cash/Bitcoin SV address (or vice versa). Is it possible to retrieve my funds?
a:
If you have sent Bitcoin Cash or Bitcoin SV to a Bitcoin Segwit-address (an address starting with a 3), it is not possible to recover the funds.
Otherwise, the answer depends on who is the recipient of the transaction:

• You: your private keys (and passphrases) for Bitcoin wallets are valid for Bitcoin Cash and Bitcoin SV wallets and vice versa, so you just need to export and import your keys (passphrases). Please contact your wallet if you need help with this.
  • An exchange (Bittrex, Poloniex, Binance, etc.): in this case, you should contact the exchange support.
  • Your friend or colleague: you could ask the recipient to install the second wallet and explain that he has to import his private key into that wallet. Please contact your wallet if you need help with this.

faq.q: Is it possible to retrieve Ethereum that I deposited to an ERC-20 address (or vice versa)?
faq.a: If you made a deposit on an exchange and sent Ethereum to an ERC-20 address (or vice versa), please contact the exchange to find out if they can retrieve your funds. If you sent Ethereum to an ERC-20 address (or vice versa) which you control, you should be able to retrieve the funds. We cannot help you with this, your wallet can explain how to do this.

faq.q: Is it possible to retrieve Ethereum or ERC20s tokens that I sent to a Binance Smart Chain address (or vice versa)?
a: If you sent funds on the Ethereum network to a BSC address (or vice versa) and you are the owner of the private key belonging to the BSC address, then you should import the private key of the BSC address into an Ethereum wallet (for example Metamask). You will then be able to move the funds again on the Ethereum network. This also works the other way around.
Please note that not all wallets and exchanges technically support retrieving funds. Please contact your wallet or exchange to see if it’s possible to retrieve your funds.
If you wish to send your Ethereum or ERC20 tokens to the BSC network (or vice versa), then you should use the Binance Bridge.

faq.a: In public blockchain networks, miners verify transactions in blocks and are rewarded with transaction fees and newly minted coins. In Bitcoin and several other blockchains, the number of newly minted coins per block is cut in half every 4 years, so inflation is limited. In Bitcoin networks, the reward started with 50 BTC per block, which has already been halved to 6.25 BTC per block. For more information, check out our halving countdown dashboard.

faq-why.title: Why is my transaction not arriving
faq-why.text: When your transaction remains unconfirmed on our explorer, your transaction has most likely not been processed because of a low transaction fee. You should contact your wallet or exchange to receive information about how to increase your transaction fee. Blockchair does not process transactions and can not help you with increasing your transaction fee.

items.q: Why is my transaction not arriving?
a: It can take quite some time before your transaction is processed: several minutes, hours, sometimes several days, and in some cases, it seems your transaction will never be processed!

We understand that this is annoying, but Blockchair cannot help you speed up your transaction → if you continue reading you will find out why your transaction is being processed slowly and what you can do to speed up your transaction.

items.q: Why are transactions being processed slowly?
a: Transactions on blockchain networks are processed in blocks and every block has a block limit (Bitcoin) or gas limit (Ethereum). This limits the number of transactions that can be processed in a block. In the Bitcoin network, approximately every 10 minutes a new block is processed, with approximately 3,000 transactions in them. In the Ethereum network, approximately every 13 seconds a new block is processed, with currently a maximum of 590 transactions in them.

Currently, there are {bitcoin_transactions} transactions in the Bitcoin network waiting to be processed and {ethereum_transactions} transactions in the Ethereum network. The place where non-processed transactions are stored is called the mempool.

To have your transaction prioritized by miners over other transactions, you can attach a transaction fee to your transaction that incentivizes miners to include your transaction in a block quicker. If you have been waiting for a long period for your transaction to be processed, the most likely reason is a low transaction fee.
<cite>Blockchair does not process transactions, so we are unable to prioritize processing your transaction over other transactions.</cite>

items.q: What can I do to speed up my transaction?
a: For Bitcoin transactions:
If your transaction has replace-by-fee (RBF) enabled, then you technically have the ability to resend the transaction with a higher transaction fee. You should resend it using your wallet.
If RBF is not enabled, then you should wait until your transaction is processed or dropped from the mempool.
For Ethereum transactions:
You should increase the transaction fee (gas price). The new parameters should be set in your wallet or by your exchange.

Not every wallet or exchange supports the function to increase the transaction fee. To check whether your wallet or exchange supports increasing the transaction fee or not, you should contact your wallet or exchange. There is nothing Blockchair can do to increase your transaction fee and have your transaction processed faster, unfortunately.

Warning!

Beware of scammers! No one can reverse your transaction and only YOU have the power to speed up your transaction. Don’t fall for scammers impersonating members of Blockchair! We will never ask for your private keys, seed phrase or mnemonic phrase.

We will not write to you first, be that in a private message on Telegram or other social media, and we do not provide support for individual requests which are unrelated to Blockchair’s products and services.

advertise.title:
Reach out directly
to the active crypto users
advertise.subtitle: Blockchair is one of the few unique places where you can advertise  directly to individuals who transact crypto on a daily basis.
advertise.text: Advertise on Blockchair where users come to check information about their recent transactions and on-chain activity. Get more exposure among your real target audience and increase your client base.
points: Optimize your ad budgets by targeting only the active crypto users
Access global crypto audience. Get mobile and desktop leads
Promote your business among the audience coming from the industry leaders
Native ad format that matches the website's design
advertise.form_caption: Optimize your marketing budget by targeting active crypto audience
advertise.form_form_caption: Our sales team will contact you shortly to discuss the advertising options and answer any questions you might have.
advertise.options_title_caption: Depending on the size of the referral traffic, we offer 3 options for the partnership:

options.title: Top buttons
options.text:
Target users through a concise button with the native design: ‘Buy Crypto’, ‘Exchange’, ‘Earn Interest’, ‘Gamble’, or your own idea.

The button is shown on the transaction, address, block, and index pages for all the blockchains we support.

Once clicked, the user is redirected to your website right away.

options.title: Footer buttons
options.text:
Target users through a Footer page button with the native design.

These buttons allow you to add more context to the ad you wish to promote. Increase your ad’s visibility by merging 2 small buttons into 1 large button.

The button is shown on all pages, except for Home and API pages.

Once clicked, the user is redirected to your website right away.

options.title: Native sentence
options.text:
Target users with a native sentence, for a specific blockchain (for example: only at Bitcoin and Ethereum pages), or for a specific topic (only on transaction pages).

Once clicked, the user is redirected to your website right away.

advertise.contact_title: Target the niche Blockchain and Crypto audience
advertise.contact_caption: Get more exposure among your real target audience and increase yor client base.

pom.h4:
We use 100+ indicators to measure the privacy scores of Bitcoin transactions.

In some cases the score may be improved, while some indicators are dependent on the software used to interact with the Bitcoin blockchain. Such privacy issues are not possible to fix unless the user changes the app or website used.

status_description.critical: The identified issues are significantly endangering the privacy of the parties involved. Usually, the critical score is shown when it is possible to group the addresses that belong to the same owner or when the transaction has a lot of privacy issues.
status_description.low: The identified issues are severely jeopardizing the privacy of the parties involved. Usually the Low score is assigned to the transactions with a lot of privacy issues.
status_description.moderate: The identified issues are not that severe but can still be used by tracking tools to trace your transactions.
status_description.high: The identified issues are negligible and do not pose a serious threat to the privacy of involved parties/addresses.
status_description.healthy: The transaction has no privacy issues. Third parties can’t extract any privacy-related information about the transaction or addresses involved.

pom.pom_description: Privacy-o-meter shows the level of traceability of a transaction via various tracking tools
pom.issue_addresses_description: Using several indicators we were able to link the similar types of addresses involved in this transaction. We identified which of the recipient addresses possibly belong to one or more senders. Such matching significantly reduces the anonymity of addresses.
pom.issue_possible_to_fix: Issues that are possible to fix
pom.guideline_title: General guidelines for sending BTC transactions
pom.guideline_description:
Blockchair can not help you improve the privacy of your
transactions but here are some basic recommendations
on how to stay anonymous on the Bitcoin network

guideline1.title: Don't send round numbers
guideline1.description: Don't send round amounts. Instead of sending 0.1 BTC, send 0.10125

guideline2.title: Use Bitcoin Mixers
guideline2.description: Mixers add an additional layer of privacy to a transaction to avoid exposing user identities.

guideline3.title: Avoid reusing wallets
guideline3.description: Don't send your Bitcoin change to the same address you use for sending bitcoins.

guideline4.title: Avoid including many of your addresses in one transaction
guideline4.description: Any time you can, try not to send BTC from your various Bitcoin addresses.

guideline5.title: Avoid using "send everything" option
guideline5.description:
If you are withdrawing funds from an exchange, it is okay.
If you're moving funds to another wallet, do not transfer the whole amount to another address. It greatly compromises your privacy.

pom.guideline_detailed: The detailed list of indicators and recommendations are available in API docs

form.title: Get privacy scores with Blockchair API for free
form.scores_caption:
For all privacy-oriented wallets and services
who wish to feature and link to the Privacy-o-meter

intro.check: Check the privacy level of your Bitcoin transactions.
intro.is_vulnerable: The privacy-o-meter shows whether your transaction is vulnerable to tracking indicators used by numerous tracing tools.

inputs.title: Co-spending
inputs.description: Unless it's a CoinJoin transaction it's safe to assume that all input addresses belong to one person
inputs.suggestion: Try not to send a BTC amount higher than you hold on one of your addresses. If you value your privacy on Bitcoin more than the transaction costs, then opt to send fewer transactions. Your addresses will not be linked to each other.

script_types.title: Script types
script_types.description: If all inputs has the same type, and exactly one of the outputs is not of the same type — this output can be considered as the recipient

p2sh_types.title: P2SH multisig types
p2sh_types.description: If all inputs are [m] of [n] multisig P2SH, and all outputs are multisig P2SH, but exactly one of the outputs has another [m] of [n] structure — this output can be considered as the recipient

p2wsh_types.title: P2WSH multisig types
p2wsh_types.description: If all inputs are [m] of [n] multisig P2WSH, and all outputs are multisig P2WSH, but exactly one of the outputs has another [m] of [n] structure — this output can be considered as the recipient

round_value.title: Round value
round_value.description: If one of the outputs has a round value (like exactly 1 BTC) — this output can be considered as the recipient
round_value.suggestion: Next time don't send round values: instead of sending 0.1 BTC, send for example 0.10124.

recipient_by_value.title: Recipient by bigger value
recipient_by_value.description: If the recipient is the smaller output, there's no point in having some of the inputs
recipient_by_value.suggestion: Try not to send a BTC amount higher than you hold on one of your addresses. If you value your privacy on Bitcoin more than the transaction costs, then opt to send fewer transactions. Your addresses will not be linked to each other.

t1-2_bigger_value_25.title: Output value x25
t1-2_bigger_value_25.description: One of the two outputs is 25 times bigger than the other meaning that it's potentially the change output
t1-2_bigger_value_25.suggestion: Next time, try to use the address where you hold a smaller amount of BTC to avoid recognizing your change address among recipients.

t1-2_bigger_value_100.title: Output value x100
t1-2_bigger_value_100.description: One of the two outputs is 100 times bigger than the other meaning that it's potentially the change output
t1-2_bigger_value_100.suggestion: Next time, try to use the address where you hold a smaller amount of BTC to avoid recognizing your change address among recipients.

t1-2_bigger_value_250.title: Output value x250
t1-2_bigger_value_250.description: One of the two outputs is 250 times bigger than the other meaning that it's potentially the change output
t1-2_bigger_value_250.suggestion: Next time, try to use the address where you hold a smaller amount of BTC to avoid recognizing your change address among recipients.

t1-2_bigger_value_1000.title: Output value x1000
t1-2_bigger_value_1000.description: One of the two outputs is 1000 times bigger than the other meaning that it's potentially the change output
t1-2_bigger_value_1000.suggestion: Next time, try to use the address where you hold a smaller amount of BTC to avoid recognizing your change address among recipients.

coinbase_known.title: Known miner
coinbase_known.description: The recipient is the known miner

coinbase_unknown.title: Unknown miner
coinbase_unknown.description: The recipient is an unknown miner

coinjoin.title: Coinjoin
coinjoin.description: This is a CoinJoin transaction. This cancels all other heuristics.
coinjoin.suggestion: Using CoinJoin is great. It protects your anonymity. Keep it up.

round_fee.title: Round fee
round_fee.description: The transaction has a round fee amount, the sender is probably using specific software.

rare_fingerprint.title: Rare fingerprint
rare_fingerprint.description: This transaction has quite unique technical characteristics.

asc_output_values.title: Ascending output values
asc_output_values.description: For transaction with more than 5 outputs — they are ordered by ascending value — which may be due to some specific software usage.

desc_output_values.title: Descending output values
desc_output_values.description: For transaction with more than 5 outputs — they are ordered by descending value — which may be due to some specific software usage.

asc_output_addresses.title: Ascending output addresses
asc_output_addresses.description: For transaction with more than 5 outputs — they are ordered by addresses in alphabetical order — that may due to some specific software usage

desc_output_addresses.title: Descending output addresses
desc_output_addresses.description: For transaction with more than 5 outputs — they are ordered by addresses in alphabetical order — that may due to some specific software usage

asc_input_values.title: Ascending input values
asc_input_values.description: For transaction with more than 5 inputs — they are ordered by value ascending — that may due to some specific software usage

desc_input_values.title: Descending input values
desc_input_values.description: For transaction with more than 5 inputs — they are ordered by value descending — that may due to some specific software usage

asc_input_addresses.title: Ascending input addresses
asc_input_addresses.description: For transaction with more than 5 inputs — they are ordered by addresses in alphabetical order — that may due to some specific software usage

desc_input_addresses.title: Descending input addresses
desc_input_addresses.description: For transaction with more than 5 inputs — they are ordered by addresses in alphabetical order — that may due to some specific software usage

asc_input_timestamps.title: Ascending input timestamps
asc_input_timestamps.description: For transaction with more than 5 inputs — they are ordered by age — that may due to some specific software usage

desc_input_timestamps.title: Descending input timestamps
desc_input_timestamps.description: For transaction with more than 5 inputs — they are ordered by age — that may due to some specific software usage

asc_output_values_except_first.title: Ascending output values except first
asc_output_values_except_first.description: All outputs are sorted by value ascending except for the first one, that may mean that the first output is the change address.

asc_output_values_except_last.title: Ascending output values except last
asc_output_values_except_last.description: All outputs are sorted by value ascending except for the last one, that may mean that the first output is the change address.

asc_output_addresses_except_first.title: Ascending output addresses except first
asc_output_addresses_except_first.description: All outputs are sorted by addresses in alphabetical order except for the first one, that may mean that the first output is the change address.

asc_output_addresses_except_last.title: Ascending output addresses except last
asc_output_addresses_except_last.description: All outputs are sorted by addresses in alphabetical order except for the last one, that may mean that the first output is the change address.

desc_output_values_except_first.title: Descending output values except first
desc_output_values_except_first.description: All outputs are sorted by value descending except for the last one, that may mean that the last output is the change addres

desc_output_values_except_last.title: Descending output values except last
desc_output_values_except_last.description: All outputs are sorted by value descending except for the last one, that may mean that the last output is the change address

desc_output_addresses_except_last.title: Descending output addresses except last
desc_output_addresses_except_last.description: All outputs are sorted by address alphabetically descending except for the last one, that may mean that the last output is the change address

desc_output_addresses_except_first.title: Descending output addresses except first
desc_output_addresses_except_first.description: All outputs are sorted by address alphabetically descending except for the first one, that may mean that the first output is the change address

simple_reuse_1-2.title: Address reuse
simple_reuse_1-2.description: The sender uses the same address for receiving and for change

simple_reuse_N-2.title: Address reuse
simple_reuse_N-2.description: The sender uses the same address for receiving and for change

simple_reuse_1-N.title: Address reuse
simple_reuse_1-N.description: The sender (probably an exchange) uses the same address for receiving and for change

simple_reuse_same_address_in_inputs.title: Same address in inputs
simple_reuse_same_address_in_inputs.description: There's multiple occurences of the same address in inputs

sweep_1-1.title: Sweep (1-1)
sweep_1-1.description: The sender uses the 'send everything' option to either pay someone (e.g. an exchange) or just moving the funds to another wallet (1 input)
sweep_1-1.suggestion: If you are withdrawing funds from an exchange, it is okay. If you're moving funds to another wallet, do not transfer the whole amount to another address. It greatly compromises your privacy.

sweep_1-1_to_another_type.title: Sweep to another type (1-1)
sweep_1-1_to_another_type.description: The sender uses the "send everything" option to either pay someone or move the funds to a new wallet type (1 input)
sweep_1-1_to_another_type.suggestion: If you are withdrawing funds from an exchange, it is okay. If you're moving funds to another wallet, do not transfer the whole amount to another address. It greatly compromises your privacy.

sweep_N-1.title: Sweep
sweep_N-1.description: The sender uses the "send everything" option to either pay someone (e.g. an exchange) or just moving the funds to another wallet
sweep_N-1.suggestion: If you are withdrawing funds from an exchange, it is okay. If you're moving funds to another wallet, try to avoid sending everything at once. It greatly compromises your privacy.

sweep_N-1_to_another_type.title: Sweep to another type
sweep_N-1_to_another_type.description: The sender uses the "send everything" option to either pay someone (e.g. an exchange) or just moving the funds to another wallet of another type than the initial addresses
sweep_N-1_to_another_type.suggestion: If you are withdrawing funds from an exchange, it is okay. If you're moving funds to another wallet, do not transfer the whole amount to another address. It greatly compromises your privacy.

discrepancy_unnecessary_inputs.title: Discrepancy: unnecessary input
discrepancy_unnecessary_inputs.description: The smaller input is unnecessary, as whichever of the outputs is the recipient, there's no need to include that input
discrepancy_unnecessary_inputs.suggestion: The smaller input address is uneccessarily added to the transaction. Avoid doing this.

discrepancy_various_input_types.title: Discrepancy: various input types
discrepancy_various_input_types.description: The inputs are of different types. That means the sender is probably using the software allowing to create the same address type for the change as the recipient has, trying to circumvent the script_types heuristic

discrepancy_script_types_and_round_value.title: Discrepancy between Script types and Round value

discrepancy_script_types_and_recipient_b.title: Discrepancy between Script types and Recipient by value
discrepancy_script_types_and_recipient_b.description: [script_types] and [recipient by value] heuristics yield different results.

discrepancy_round_value_and_recipient_by.title: Discrepancy between Round value and Recipient by value
discrepancy_round_value_and_recipient_by.description: [round_value] and [recipient by value] heuristics yield different results.

discrepancy_p2sh_various_input_types.title: Discrepancy: various P2SH input types
discrepancy_p2sh_various_input_types.description: The P2SH input types are different (e.g. one is 2-of-2 multisig, and the other is 2-of-3). Very rare.

discrepancy_p2wsh_various_input_types.title: Discrepancy: various P2WSH input types
discrepancy_p2wsh_various_input_types.description: The P2WSH input types are different (e.g. one is 2-of-2 multisig, and the other is 2-of-3). Very rare.

discrepancy_same_address_in_outputs.title: Discrepancy: output address duplicates
discrepancy_same_address_in_outputs.description: There are outputs with the same address — that makes no economical sense.
discrepancy_same_address_in_outputs.suggestion: It is not recommended to repeat addresses among the list of Recipients. It is unnecessary and costly.

discrepancy_no_output_of_the_same_type_a.title: Discrepancy: no output of the same type as inputs
discrepancy_no_output_of_the_same_type_a.description: The sender probably uses software generating the same change address type as the recipient address has.

pom.software_dependent: Software-dependent issues that are not fixable

partnerships.title: Become a Blockchair Partner
partnerships.caption:
Refer users to the classic or customized Blockchair Explorer
and enjoy great benefits and discounts
title_points: Are you a wallet, exchange, or a similar crypto service?
Do you need to show these ugly hashes and addresses in your user interface?
Are you showing transactions in plain text to your users?
Do you link to crappy block explorers that aren`t user friendly?

cards.title: Better service
cards.caption: You’ll make your users happy as they won’t have to deal with crappy block explorers anymore

cards.title: SEO
cards.caption: Backlinks from us will increase your brand awareness and improve your search engine ranks

cards.title: Up to 10% off
cards.caption: On Blockchair services including API and Data dumps

cards.title: Partner
cards.caption: We will promote your application or service on our Awesome List among the biggest market players

cards.title: Promo
cards.caption: We will feature your product in the Useful Links sections on Blockchair’s most visited pages

points: The first block explorer that combines the most popular cryptocurrencies
Simple, neat, and convenient platform interface your users understand and love
Support for {blockchains_count} blockchains and thousands of ERC-20 tokens in one place
Only the info users need, no address scripts and child calls
Platform available in {languages_count} languages. Translated by specialists for the convenience of your users.
Created keeping newbies in mind. Super-easy to understand the status of user’s transaction

middle.title: We care about privacy
middle.text: User privacy matters to us the most. We never include third party trackers to our web interface. Google will never know your user’s balance. We do not store user logs, nor do we sell them. For more info, refer to our Privacy Policy.

middle.title: We love decentralization
middle.text: As decentralization matters to us, we include links to other block explorers so our users can double-check their transactions. We believe users shouldn’t be tied just to one source of information, that’s why we encourage app developers to include links to block explorers such as ours.

partnerships.how-to_caption: Depending on the size of the referral traffic, we offer 3 options for the partnership:

how-to_points.title: Redirect users to Blockchair Explorer
how-to_points.text:
By embedding the referral links to Blockchair you'll help your users get a clear view of what is going on with their transaction, whether it got to the mempool, or was confirmed already.

We will also add you to our Useful links section on the most visited pages on Blockchair.

how-to_points.title:
Redirect users
to the Сo-branded explorer
how-to_points.text:
If you have an app or a service with lots of users and are interested in expanding your brand, we recommend you to reach out to us. We will build a co-branded explorer for you, which helps in creating a stronger brand image, and increases the user’s trust level.

In the explorer itself, we can add your logo to the site’s header, or change some colors. You will also have the possibility to adjust the number of confirmations for each blockchain (e.g. the default for Bitcoin is 6, but your service may only wait for 3 confirmations), as well as to hide the Privacy-o-meter from the interface for Bitcoin blockchain.

how-to_points.title:
💰 Earn for each referred user
+ Co-branded explorer
how-to_points.text:
Do you have the ability to refer lots of users to Blockchair’s explorer? Refer to Blockchair by installing backlinks to us and earn referral revenue. Receive the referral revenue each 3 months for being an awesome partner.

We will build a Co-branded explorer for you, with your logo and colors, and you`ll have the possibility to adjust the number of confirmations for each blockchain (e.g. the default for Bitcoin is 6, but your service may only wait for 3 confirmations), as well as to hide the Privacy-o-meter from the interface for Bitcoin blockchain. All of this, free of charge.

partnerships.how_to_bch_address: It`s possible to use both legacy address format and CashAddr
partnerships.how_to_eth_address:
Address shoud start with 
0x
, supported both simple accounts and contracts
partnerships.discuss_title:
To discuss partnership and cooperation
opportunities please contact our team

dumps.db_text: For some tasks like extracting lots of blockchain data (e.g. all transactions over a 2 month period) it's better to use our dumps feature instead of using our API or other services. It's possible to download the entire database dumps in TSV format and insert the data onto your own database server (like Postgresql or whatever) to further analyze it. Dumps are updated daily. The total amount of data available is over 1 Tb (compressed)!
dumps.db_list: Here's the list of available dumps:
dumps.node_text: Since syncing a full node can take quite some time (for example, syncing a full archival Ethereum node takes more than a month) we decided to make it possible to download data snapshots. Once you've downloaded a snapshot you'd need just to put it to a correct data folder and run the node.
dumps.node_list: Here is the list of snapshots we're providing:
dumps.node_available: Our node dumps are available here:
dumps.node_limits: You can download 1 file at a time and the speed is limited to 10 kB/s. If you are a business or an academia/non-profit organisation that requires a higher speed, please contact us at
